answers.answer: I think what you do have is some neuropathy.  I also had chemo, and got neuropathy from that, a fairly common event in some chemo people.  It subsided in my hands over many months after chemo was done, but my feet still are rather affected.  Next time you are scheduled to see your cancer doc, obviously mention this to him, he may be able to prescribe something to ease the discomfort in your hand.
It can be quite common to have nutritional deficiencies during Chemo.  Please let your doctor know.  It may be as simple as B12
Sounds like Neuropathy secondary to chemo.  This may or may NOT subside after completing chemo txs.

Hello dear and welcome to the medhelp forum. I can understand how distressing your situation would be. Chemotherapy induced peripheral neuropathy can result from damaged peripheral nerves. There are certain known chemotherapy drugs and anti cancer drugs which can cause these symptoms.  The effects may be pronounced if you have co existing diabetes, malnutrition, consume alcohol or had previous chemotherapy. You need to protect your hands, use gloves when doing chores, be vigilant of cuts, abrasions or burns, and apply lotions. Your chemotherapy may need to be interrupted or dose adjusted accordingly, vitamin B complex supplements etc. consult your oncologist and if needed a neurologist who may help you with antidepressants or ant seizure medications if pain develops. You may need guided physical therapy. Wishing you all the best.
